{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3410016,"name":"","username":"Echoing","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/echoing/{size}/222017_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-21T16:33:07.411Z","cooked":"

Our team is used to building live-axle arms with hex. We’d like to try something new and more robust.

How do you guys build a dead axle arm? Can it be done by only using a hex shaft?(or any downsides if only using a hex shaft for a dead axle?)

Also, a lot of teams built their intakes and flywheels using dead axle. How does that work?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-07-21T16:33:07.411Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":567,"reads":545,"readers_count":544,"score":2933.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":468952,"topic_slug":"how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61702,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6940 Former Co-Captain and Chief Engineer"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller/468952/1","custom_user_title":"6940 Former Co-Captain and Chief Engineer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3410042,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-21T17:56:49.931Z","cooked":"

For a dead axle, you can use hex, but it’s less optimal due to cost of hex bearings. Round shaft is likely to be a bit better, ay least from a cost point of view, and possibly a material availability point of view.

For dead-axle setups, you attach the sprocket (or gear or pulley) directly to the thing you are rotating, not to the axle the thing rotates on. Then you put appropriate bearings or bushings where the thing you are rotating meets the shaft. The axle is then supported at both ends–whether it rotates or not doesn’t really matter.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-07-21T17:56:49.931Z","reply_count":4,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":546,"readers_count":545,"score":194.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":468952,"topic_slug":"how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller/468952/2","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3410050,"name":"Ian Saam","username":"Enjsnake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/enjsnake/{size}/201559_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-21T18:54:37.271Z","cooked":"

In terms of dead axle hopper/intake rollers, this post on mechanical advantage’s(6328) build thread is very insightful: FRC 6328 Mechanical Advantage 2024 Build Thread - #302 by Maximillian

Would it be considered a live axle or dead axle if the arm, sprocket, and axle are all directly attached together? We’ve done a really simple system where the axle rotates on bearings pressed into the frame and then the arm and sprocket are connected through a hex hub to the axle. In this way the torque is transmitted directly through the sprocket to the arm but everything is rotating together.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-07-22T00:03:30.918Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":447,"readers_count":446,"score":99.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":468952,"topic_slug":"how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":4212,"username":"EricH","name":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57710,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller/468952/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3410118,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-22T01:05:27.148Z","cooked":"

Dead axle: Axle does not rotate - mechanism rotates around the fixed axle
Live axle: Axle rotates with the mechanism

Your example is of a live axle.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-07-22T01:05:27.148Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":410,"readers_count":409,"score":107.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":468952,"topic_slug":"how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller","display_username":"paulonis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22261,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller/468952/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3410128,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-22T02:03:23.751Z","cooked":"

Live axle that didn’t need to be live. Use the bearings between the arm and axle for simpler dead axle, connect sprockets to the axle instead of the arm for simpler (albeit likely weaker) live axle.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-07-22T02:03:23.751Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":370,"readers_count":369,"score":99.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":468952,"topic_slug":"how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57710,"username":"Durgabo","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/d6d6ee/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller/468952/6","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3410131,"name":"AllenGregoryIV","username":"AllenGregoryIV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/allengregoryiv/{size}/65531_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-22T02:13:58.692Z","cooked":"
EricH:

cost of hex bearings

This is not an issue for many teams now since you can get 1/2" rounded hex bearings for $3 each. Most teams have them in stock already.

Using hex shaft as a dead axles is convenient as if you are just tapping the shaft you can put a wrench on the hex shaft and tighten it easily.

However for arms using a larger OD shaft will make it stronger and less likely to bend. The new larger spline shafts MaxSpline/SplineXL can work well for this in some cases.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-07-22T02:13:58.692Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":348,"readers_count":347,"score":134.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":468952,"topic_slug":"how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller","display_username":"AllenGregoryIV","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":10647,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Engineering Coach - Spectrum 3847/Photon 8515"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller/468952/7","custom_user_title":"Engineering Coach - Spectrum 3847/Photon 8515","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3410156,"name":"","username":"Echoing","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/echoing/{size}/222017_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-22T05:33:43.441Z","cooked":"

How exactly to build an arm with such large OD shafts? (SplineXL for example) I mean, it’s not as straight forward as a hex shaft (simply switching the bearing from the structure to the arm itself) I don’t think there is even a bearing that big.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-07-22T05:33:43.441Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":304,"readers_count":303,"score":105.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":468952,"topic_slug":"how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":10647,"username":"AllenGregoryIV","name":"AllenGregoryIV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/allengregoryiv/{size}/65531_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61702,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6940 Former Co-Captain and Chief Engineer"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller/468952/8","custom_user_title":"6940 Former Co-Captain and Chief Engineer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3410158,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-22T05:45:09.375Z","cooked":"
Echoing:

I don’t think there is even a bearing that big

Not in the normal FRC space. But that’s not exactly a big bearing in the grand scheme of things. And it’s an even less big bushing.

In other words: Source your bearings and bushings outside the usual FRC-specific suppliers, and you’re fine. Amazon, Misumi, McMaster will all have a chance at something of the right size for your large shaft.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-07-22T05:45:09.375Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":306,"readers_count":305,"score":106.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":468952,"topic_slug":"how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller/468952/9","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3410159,"name":"AllenGregoryIV","username":"AllenGregoryIV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/allengregoryiv/{size}/65531_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-22T05:49:47.062Z","cooked":"
Echoing:

I don’t think there is even a bearing that big.

MaxSpline: MAXSpline Shaft Bearing Blocks - REV Robotics

SplineXL: WCP-1471 - Ball Bearings – WestCoast Products

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-07-22T05:49:47.062Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":301,"readers_count":300,"score":140.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":468952,"topic_slug":"how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller","display_username":"AllenGregoryIV","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://wcproducts.com/products/ball-bearings","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Ball Bearings – WestCoast Products","clicks":48},{"url":"https://www.revrobotics.com/maxspline-shaft-bearing-blocks/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"MAXSpline Shaft Bearing Blocks - REV Robotics","clicks":40}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":10647,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Engineering Coach - Spectrum 3847/Photon 8515"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller/468952/10","custom_user_title":"Engineering Coach - Spectrum 3847/Photon 8515","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3410161,"name":"","username":"s_forbes","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s_forbes/{size}/1822_2.png","created_at":"2024-07-22T06:17:33.442Z","cooked":"

For large OD dead axles, this combo has worked well for us:

Tube, Nut insert, Bushing

The bushing is big. To put a hole in the tube that rides on the dead axle we use an annular cutter in a manual mill. The tube also needs to be machined down, as the tolerances of the extrusion rarely fit the bushing. This requires a lathe with a spindle bore of at least 1.25".

This process seemed simpler before I typed it out. MaxSpline might be a better approach…

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-07-22T06:17:33.442Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":298,"readers_count":297,"score":79.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":468952,"topic_slug":"how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.mcmaster.com/2938T61/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"McMaster-Carr","clicks":26},{"url":"https://www.mcmaster.com/94290A571/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"McMaster-Carr","clicks":24},{"url":"https://www.industrialmetalsupply.com/6061-aluminum-round-tube/61t1250620","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"6061 Aluminum Round Tube | Industrial Metal Supply","clicks":21},{"url":"https://www.amazon.com/ACTOOL-Diameter-Depth-ANNULAR-CUTTER/dp/B07512LQ35","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Amazon.com","clicks":16}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":5628,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller/468952/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3410203,"name":"Chris LaSalle","username":"robo5142","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/b2d939/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-22T14:17:48.752Z","cooked":"

We used steel hex shaft for our arm and mounted our sprockets as you mentioned in your thrrad. It all worked very well for us.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2024-07-22T14:17:48.752Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":275,"readers_count":274,"score":60.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":468952,"topic_slug":"how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller","display_username":"Chris LaSalle","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":4212,"username":"EricH","name":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":47189,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-do-a-dead-axle-arm-or-roller/468952/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3410399,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-07-22T23:27:58.170Z","cooked":"
s_forbes:

For large OD dead axles, this combo has worked well for us:

Tube , Nut insert , Bushing

Without seeing CAD, just a PSA for those that might be trying this. Don’t try to support the dead axle tube with just the screws going in to the nut inserts. The inserts are great for retaining the tube axially, but not for the radial load. Support the tube with a hole in the wall of your upright, or a hole in a plate attached to your upright, or some other method of directly supporting the tube.

We dis a dead axle this year for pivoting our shooter/climber on a REV Max Tube. We used the single plates onour outside rails to hold the axle and pivoted the elevator/shooter on the 35mm bearings. We used max spline gears with the pivoting motor mounted on the elevator for positional control and it worked pretty good, a little more backlash than I liked but it worked. Here are a couple pics to help explain.

20240722_2240011920×1163 274 KB

20240722_2238271920×1600 182 KB

The rev max tube is perfect for doing this type of stuff as we used a live axle on our intake and that worked amazingly well and took some brutal hits this year and came out only slightly bent.

This year used a dead axle on a Quokka style arm. Kept it simple with a 0.5 inch case hardened steel shaft (McMaster). Supported by multiple 1/8 inch plates (over-constrained but didn’t matter as assembled the plates to the shaft first, so very short cantilevered spans). Arm pivoted on regular 1/2 inch round radial bearings, with a sprocket bolted to the arm through a custom adapter block. We had a backup design using a pair of tapered roller bearings and a more complex shaft but found it totally unnecessary. Several needle bearing bore pulleys rode on the same dead with belt pairs, to keep all our motors stationary and close to the ground. Was super reliable and low backlash.

image807×325 47.9 KB

Yup - good answer.

A common use of a dead axle is for something like an intake where the side plates are a bit floppy. The dead axle give a bit more structure to the intake as the axle provides a bit more stiffness to the structure (vs. an axle floating in bearings).
